awd_titl_txt: Agent-Based Dynamics, Nonlinear Transport, and Social Hydrodynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Nature and human societies offer many examples of collective dynamics that tend to self-organize into large-scale patterns.  The goal of this project is to study nonlinear transport equations, which give a mathematical description of diverse manifestations of collective dynamics, such as flocking of birds or movement of the population of microorganisms in response to a chemical stimulus (chemotaxis).  The principal focus of this research is on the persistence of global features of solutions of the corresponding transport equations, including their smoothing behavior, self-organization, and the emergence of patterns, such as large-scale clustering into consensus, flocking, and the emergence of leaders. The project involves graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in the research.

This research project comprises five parts: (i) A study of the ensemble of agent-based dynamics in order to predict how different rules of local engagement affect the large-time emergence of one or more clusters. (ii) A study of a new paradigm of collective dynamics, for which communication takes place along the projections of those agents that are "moving ahead." (iii) It is known that smooth solutions of collective social hydrodynamics governed by nonlinear transport must flock. The question arises, when does the smoothness of these equations persist? The regularity of nonlinear transport equations in social hydrodynamics, and their dependence on critical thresholds in the space of initial configurations will be investigated. (iv) Chemotaxis is a canonical example for group dynamics driven by (chemo-) attraction and (volume-filling) repulsion. When a population of bacteria is overcrowded, there is a repulsion peak; this calls for a new incompressible model for chemotaxis. The vanishing viscosity limit of such a "peaked" repulsion will be studied. (v) A study of nonlinear transport associated with social hydrodynamics driven by degenerate local Laplacians will be undertaken. It is planned to implement the velocity-averaging techniques used to study the regularization of nonlinear conservation laws with degenerate diffusion.

por.por_cntn:
The ultimate goal of this proposal was to study emergence and persistence of global features in nonlinear transport equations models which arise in the context of, e.g., opinion dynamics, flocking hydrodynamics and chemotaxis.

We list below five notable outcomes that were achieved towards that goal.

1. We have made substantial contributions to collective dynamics, including new paradigms based on anticipation, topologically-based distances, multi-species, singular kernels and multi-flocks.

2.  A systematic study of self-organization based on short-range communication.

3. Regularity and large time behavior of 'social' hydrodynamics.

4. Different scenarios of chemotaxis with ambient flows and with multi-species.

5. Regularizing effects in the presence of degenerate diffusion.

Attraction, repulsion and alignment are three main components which play a central role in modeling collective dynamics. When does consensus or flocking take place in alignment-based dynamics driven by local interactions? we studied how different rules of local engagement affect the large-time behavior of ensemble dynamics leading into one or more clusters. Among many contributions -- (i) we studied alignment dynamics based on short-term metric kernels -- both regular and singular kernels; (ii) we initiated the study of topologically-based interactions; (iii) we described the new feature of graph connectivity in connection with  multi-species dynamics; (iv) we provided a unified framework based on anticipation; (v) we studied flocking under external potentials (see attached figure); and  (vi) we presented a general approach for multi-scale dynamics based on multi-flocks.

Collective dynamics of large groups are governed by nonlinear transport, and it is known that smooth solutions of these equations must flock. When does the smoothness of these equations persist? we studied their dependence on critical thresholds in the space of initial configurations in one- and multi-dimensional alignment dynamics and we initiated a systematic study of collective dynamics with general 'pressure laws'. 

Chemotaxis is a canonical example for group dynamics driven by (chemo-) attraction and (volume-filling) repulsion. When the population of bacteria is `over-crowded', there is a repulsion peak leading to finite-time break down. We offered a new phenomenon --- a fast-spearheading scenario driven by the ambient flow, which prevents finite-time blow-up, well above the standard threshold in case of missing ambient flow.

In another line of research, we studied regularizing effects in nonlinear transport equations and related porous medium equation based on velocity averaging.

Another part of our research involved numerical aspects: (i) we studied the questions of entropy stability for hyperbolic system; (ii) devised a new class of well-balanced schemes for shallow-water equations; and (iii) introduced a new class of high-resolution methods -- so called TECNO schemes, for computation of measure-values solutions of multi-dimensional conservation laws.

The results were presented in major (inter-) national conferences and engaged a long list of collaborators, graduate students, and postdocs. The work of the PI with his collaborators was summarized in more than 35 publications and was awarded several distinctions.
